abstracts.cdata!:
The Banking Sector Loan for Argentina
            was approved by the Board on March 29, 1988, and again in
            amended form on October 27, 1988. It was never signed, and
            the loan was withdrawn by the Bank on October 31, 1989. As a
            result, the project is not rated. Following the original
            approval of the loan, it became clear that the Government
            would not be able to meet some of the conditions, and the
            loan was therefore amended. Subsequently, regular reviews
            showed that important conditions of effectiveness still
            could not be met and, above all, the macroeconomic
            environment remained precarious and not conducive to
            achieving the project objectives. Due to the accelerating
            inflation and macroeconomic instability in Argentina at the
            time, the cancellation was justified. Still, the preparation
            of the project contributed indirectly to the country's
            structural adjustment efforts during 1986 to 1990,
            especially through the associated policy dialogue. Several
            general lessons can be learned from this project. It
            confirms the need to avoid excessive dependency on
            institutionally fragile and highly politicized institutions,
            especially at times when the Government's political
            power is being tested. A second lesson regards the
            conditionality of the loans. Some project actions were
            carried out, but their benefits did not become apparent
            until macroeconomic conditions were normalized. Due to
            over-optimism at appraisal, the physical components of the
            program could not be implemented. Finally, this project was
            deliberately designed with safeguards to interrupt the loan
            in case the Government could not demonstrate a conducive
            macroeconomic environment, and those safeguards were effective.

abstracts.cdata!:
To help solve existing problems in
            Argentina's banking system, this Banking Sector Loan
            (BSL) Project contains a set of reforms designed to achieve:
            (1) increased deposit mobilization and confidence in the
            banking system; (ii) improved credit allocation; and (iii)
            reduction in the cost of credit.  To that end, the loan
            consists of a policy component and a technical assistance
            component.  The policy component involves a set of policy
            reforms directed at reaching the three above mentioned
            objectives.  The technical assistance component is geared to
            strengthen the banking superintendency's capabilities
            on both credit risk analysis and assessment of the overall
            financial condition of banking institutions.  This will
            allow it to take timely actions to stop unsound financial
            practices, or if necessary, to force insolvent institutions
            to exit the market at an early stage of insolvency.
